discussion.content:
Answer is correct: Process
1. Create an application for Office 365 ProPlus in Configuration Manager
2. Create a deployment type for the Office 365 ProPlus application in Configuration Manager
3. Distribute the Office 365 ProPlus application to distribution points in Configuration Manager
4. Deploy the Office 365 ProPlus application in Configuration Manager
ref: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/deploy-office-365-proplus-with-system-center-configuration-manager-2012r2#distribute-the-office-365-proplus-%20application-to-distribution-points-in-configuration-manager

comments.content: And note the detail: It doesn't say that all the computers run Windows 10, but: all computers "that" run Windows 10 are managed by using both Configuration Manager and Microsoft Intune. We don't know if they have other computers, like Windows 8.1 for example. And we have to deploy Office 365 ProPlus to "all" the computers. To include "all" we can't use Intune at this point.

discussion.content: correct. "vintage" solution but correct to limite internet traffic.
Correct me if I'm wrong, but doesn't the question state you should minimize the network links? Does uploading the files to all distribution points minimize the internet link?

comments.content:
You would only do this once. The various computers would then only download from the local distribution point.
It seems to be a very old question
The DP's reside in each of the 6 branch offices that are connected using a WAN link. You are using the WAN link to the branch office to provision the DP, not the local internet links.
The WAN is the internet though

You should get it from somewhere. So it is passed to the distribution point once. They distribute among units under them. They can transfer installation during off hours or when network load is light. We have been doing this using SCCM for a long time.

questions.answer_description:
Deploy the Microsoft 365 Apps application in Configuration Manager.
After the files for the Microsoft 365 Apps application are copied to the appropriate distribution points, the next step is to deploy the application. When you deploy the application, you specify which computers or users get the application and when.
To deploy the application:
1. In the Configuration Manager console, choose Software Library > Application Management > Applications.
2. Select the Microsoft 365 Apps application, and then on the Home tab, in the Deployment group, choose Deploy.
3. Etc.
Note: If you use Microsoft Endpoint Configuration Manager to deploy software, such as Office, to users and computers in your organization, you can also use that existing Configuration Manager environment to deploy Microsoft 365 Apps. By using Configuration Manager, you can control which users and computers get
Microsoft 365 Apps, where they get the installation files from, and when the Microsoft 365 Apps installation occurs.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/deploy-office-365-proplus-with-system-center-configuration-manager-2012r2#distribute-the-office-365-proplus- application-to-distribution-points-in-configuration-manager

choices.A: From Intune, configure app assignments for the Office 365 ProPlus suite. In each office, copy the Office 365 distribution files to a Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) deployment share.
choices.D: From Endpoint Configuration Manager, create an application deployment. In each office, copy the Office 365 distribution files to a Configuration Manager distribution point.
choices.C: From Endpoint Configuration Manager, create an application deployment. Copy the Office 365 distribution files to a Configuration Manager cloud distribution point.
choices.B: From Intune, configure app assignments for the Office 365 ProPlus suite. In each office, copy the Office 365 distribution files to a Configuration Manager distribution point.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a main office and six branch offices. The branch offices connect to the main office by using a WAN link. All offices have a local Internet connection and a Hyper-V host cluster.
The company has a Microsoft Endpoint Configuration Manager deployment. The main office is the primary site. Each branch office has a distribution point.
All computers that run Windows 10 are managed by using both Configuration Manager and Microsoft Intune.
You plan to deploy the latest build of Microsoft Office 365 ProPlus to all the computers.
You need to minimize the amount of network traffic on the company's Internet links for the planned deployment.
What should you include in the deployment plan?

discussion.content:
Answer is correct: 
To turn on sideloading for managed devices

Deploy an enterprise policy.
To turn on sideloading for unmanaged devices

Open Settings.

Click Update & Security > For developers.

On Use developer features, select Sideload apps
To install the app

From the folder with the appx package, run the PowerShell Add-AppxPackage command to install the appx package.
REf: 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/application-management/sideload-apps-in-windows-10

Link provided states that users can also click the .appx package to install it.

"
Important
To install an app on Windows client, you can:

Install Windows apps from a web page.
Users can double-click any .msix or .appx package
"
Good answer!

The more correct is running the PowerShell cmdlet. Got this on a KAPLAN exam practice.

discussion.content:

 From the folder with the appx package, run the PowerShell Add-AppxPackage command to install the appx package.

Important!
To install an app on Windows 10, in addition to following these procedures, users can also double-click any APPX/MSIX package.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your company has a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10 Pro.
The company develops a proprietary Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app named App1. App1 is signed with a certificate from a trusted certification authority
(CA).
You need to sideload App1 to Computer1.
What should you do? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Configure the For developers settings in the Settings app
How to allow Windows 10 to sideload apps on your computer
1. Open Settings.
2. Click on Update & security.
3. Click on For developers.
4. Under "Use developer features," select the Sideload apps option.
5. Click Yes to confirm the risks involved running an app outside the Windows Store.
6. Restart your computer if applicable to complete the task.
Box 2: Run the Add-AppxPackage cmdlet
Install the App.
From the folder with the .msix package, run the Windows PowerShell Add-AppxPackage command to install the .msix package.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/application-management/sideload-apps-in-windows-10

discussion.content: i think it' the best with Intune >the Latest version must be always installed

Instead of "The solution must minimize administrative effort" it said "Your solution must also follow the principle of least amount of privilege. What is the best command-line tool to use for the deployment?"

The answer options were the same. The answer to this question was: Office Deployment Toolkit (ODT)

is still question still valid?

comments.content: If you arrived at this point, memorize this one also.

discussion.content: A :intune - you don't have to distibute content to dp...... less administrative effort.

comments.content:
It's a choice between CM and Intune. If only they said, minimise internet traffic like in previous questions.

I would go with CM. MDT is used for OSD, the org prefers traditional methods.

discussion.content:
Intune --> Create device group --> Select o365 app --> deploy to group
ODT --> Download files -> create XML --> how to trigger install (manual install/MDT Task seq/powershell script/logon script etc)
SCCM --> create new package via ODT or via wizard --> select DPs to distribute -->deploy to collection
MDT --> requires ODT to have latest version, but is fastest with install as O365 is installed during TS, so at the end I would use this in production, but is not wat MS asks.

In that regards I would say Intune is from total clicks the least, but its a bit ambiguous question.

I would go for Intune as well. You can create a deployment via Intune to deploy O365. Even with additional settings. Or just upload an xml to Intune. (this is required to create for ODT/SCCM etc as well) so it nog extra work. Intune will than automatically deploy the latest version to the group of devices you set.

In the question it states the machines are in co-management, which indicates the presence of ConfigMgr and Intune otherwise machines cannot be co-managed. In configMgr there is a co-management workload you can move to Intune specifically for Office 365 management. Office deployment and management from intune is by far the most simple way to deploy the Office apps (MS 365 Apps for business) I would lean towards Intune for this one.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/configmgr/comanage/workloads#office-click-to-run-apps

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/apps-add-office365#select-microsoft-365-apps
Jeez, I've done it Intune and it doesn't get any easier than that....
Since they're still using MDT and it wants the latest version you can use ODT with /configure to install O365 directly from the Microsoft website.

It's A & E
The question says multiple answer cab achieve the goal

Several others have posted the same link and stated that ODT is the way to go, when the link clearly says in step 1 that if you have SCCM, to deploy this way. Persoanlly I think the easiest way would be Intune as you don't need to download source files and create package as you would in ODT, MDT or SCCM. discussion.content:
IMHO i've deployed O365 ProPlus many times and i'd say it's the least administrative effort.
It also keeps it uptodate automatically. 
ODT is a lot more work compared to what needs to be done for Intune
Also ODT needs "local storage" to host the files and needs configuration.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/overview-office-deployment-tool 
Intune is way more automated with only Cloud configuration
https://docs.microsoft.com/nl-nl/mem/intune/apps/apps-add-office365

Answer is correct: ODT.. below link explain it further.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/plan-office-365-proplus

comments.content:
Best practice: If you use Configuration Manager already, make sure you are on the current branch and use it to deploy Office from distributions points on your network. If you don't have Configuration Manager, use the Office Deployment Tool and deploy Office from the cloud. If your network capacity doesn't allow for that, deploy Office with the ODT from a local source. We recommend self-install for situations in which you require less administrative control and you have the network capacity to have your users install directly from the Office portal.
IT's ODT

discussion.content: The solution must minimize the administrative effort is the question here. Could have gone with SCCM or Intune if the question was asking for the best recommended way to deploy. The answer is ODT as it reduces the administrative overhead. Check the same link shared by bobboobsmith.

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You have 10 computers that run Windows 10 and are enrolled in mobile device management (MDM).
You need to deploy the Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise suite to all the computers.
What should you do?

questions.answer_description:
Before you can assign, monitor, configure, or protect apps, you must add them to Intune. One of the available app types is Microsoft 365 apps for Windows 10 devices. By selecting this app type in Intune, you can assign and install Microsoft 365 apps to devices you manage that run Windows 10.

Note: Review + create -
1. Review the values and settings you entered for the app suite.
2. When you are done, click Create to add the app to Intune.
3. The Overview blade is displayed.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/apps-add-office365
